Despite steady growth of 7% per annum over 3 decades, Bhutan 
remains  a  poor  country  with  a  national  poverty  rate  of  32%.  The 
economy is  not sufficiently diversified, and growth has depended 
heavily  on  the  hydropower  sector,  which  accounts  for  45%  of

weak private sector. Thus, to sustain growth in the medium term,

country’s  private  sector  and

Despite strong economic growth in recent years, Bhutan remains a small economy and a 
poor country with a national poverty rate of 32%. Real economic growth has averaged about 7% 
since 1970s, and gross domestic product (GDP) per capita has increased from $51 in 1960 to 
$834 in 2005. The GDP was approximately $673 million, and national revenues $760 million, in 
2005.  However,  economic  growth  has  been  narrowly  based,  driven  mainly  by  growth  in  the 
hydropower sector and its related industries, which account for about 12% of the country’s GDP 
and 45% of national revenues. As the hydropower sector has low employment elasticity, such 
high dependence on hydropower development and limited involvement from the private sector 
pose  a  challenge  for  the  country  as  the  labor  market  seeks  to  absorb  the  growing  number  of 
new  entrants.  An  estimated  50,000  young  people  will  enter  the  labor  market,  and  another 
20,000 people will migrate from rural to urban areas by 2007. The Government therefore places 
a high priority to private sector development to diversify economic activity, stimulate economic 
growth, and generate employment. To achieve this, developing the country’s financial sector is 
necessary  to  improve  access  to  finance,  diversify  existing  financial services,  and  enhance  the 
investment environment overall. 
 
3. 
 In  parallel  with  low  business  activity,  the  financial  sector  in  Bhutan  remains  relatively 
small  and  underdeveloped.  It  comprises  the  banking  sector  and  non-bank  financial  sector. 
There are two commercial banks in the banking sector, the Bank of Bhutan Limited (BOBL) and 
the Bhutan National Bank Limited (BNBL). The two non-bank financial institutions (NBFIs) are 
Bhutan  Development  Finance  Corporation  Limited  (BDFCL)  and 
Insurance 
Corporation  of  Bhutan  Limited  (RICBL).  There  is  a  National  Pension  and  Provident  Fund 
(NPPF). Bhutan also has a stock exchange, the Royal Securities Exchange of Bhutan Limited 
(RSEBL), four securities brokers,2 and a depository.  
 
4. 
Much  of  Bhutan’s  financial  development  to  date  has  related  to  the  monetization  and 
mobilization  of  government  and  private  savings.  Financial  deepening,  measured  by  the  broad 
money-to-GDP ratio, has increased considerably from 31.7% in 1996 to 52.7% in 2005, due to 
increases  in  government  and  corporate  deposits  in  commercial  banks.  However,  the  private 
sector  has played  a  relatively  minor  role  in  the  evolution  of  the  financial  sector.  Private  sector 
credit  as  a  percentage  of  total  domestic  credit  has  declined  from  84.1%  in  2001  to  75.2%  in

Inadequate Legal and Regulatory Framework  

 
15. 
The  financial  sector  is  small  and,  as  a  whole,  not  adequately  regulated  or  supervised. 
RMA  is  the  sole  regulator  and  supervisor  of  the  financial  system,  including  the  securities 
exchange. The authority to regulate and supervise is delegated under the RMA of Bhutan Act 
(1982),  FIA  (1992),  and  Prudential  Regulations  (2002).  However,  under  existing  laws,  the 
regulatory  framework  and  guidelines  are  ill-defined,  particularly  for  insurance  and  pensions. 
Regulation  and  supervision  are  also  ineffective  for  lack  of  institutional  capacity,  non-
enforcement, and inconsistency with international standards and best practices. Therefore, the 
first  priority  of  financial  sector  development  is  to  fill  the  gaps  under  the  existing  laws  and 
regulations  to  enable  adequate  oversight  over  the  whole  financial  system  to  promote  a  sound 
and  stable  investment  environment  conducive  to  private  sector  growth  and  economic 
development.  The  issues  to  be  addressed  for  strengthening  the  existing  legal  and  regulatory 
framework follow.

26. 
Financial  crimes  such  as  money  laundering  and  financing  terrorism  can  seriously 
threaten the integrity and safety of financial systems. A financial system that allows proceeds of 
crime  to  be  easily  laundered  and  concealed  will  significantly  erode  investor  confidence  and 
divert  resources  to  less  productive  activities.  Such  erosion  of  confidence  will  have  a  negative 
impact  on  economic  growth.  The  Government  is  aware  of  such  risks  and  has  in  place  certain 
AML/CFT  provisions  in  a  number  of  different  statutes,  such  as  in  the  Penal  Code  and  the 
Narcotics  Act  (2005).  AML/CFT  provisions  for  the  banks  are  contained  in  the  Prudential 
Regulations  (2002).  These  impose  certain  basic  requirements  for  banks  to  record  suspicious 
transactions  and  to  adopt  customer  due  diligence  and  know-your-customer  procedures. 
However,  due  to  limited  understanding  of  the  provisions  and  their  impacts,  the  absence  of 
coordination  among  government  agencies  (i.e.,  RMA,  police,  and  customs),  and  the  lack  of 
effective  reporting  and  monitoring  procedures,  there  is  no  properly  coordinated  regulatory 
framework, supervision, or effective enforcement of the AML/CFT laws. Bhutan is still vulnerable 
to having illegal funds and terrorist funding routed to the country. 
 
Besides  the  lack  of  a  comprehensive  AML/CFT  legal  framework  or  effective  regulatory

4. 

Lack of National Accounting and Auditing Policies and Standards 

 
28. 
Bhutan does not have standard national accounting (and auditing) systems, and different 
regulatory authorities adopt different standards (e.g., the Department of Revenue and Customs 
has one set of norms for the treatment of foreign exchange differences and RMA another set). 
Also,  no  guideline  or  document  on  disclosure  requirements  exists  to  elaborate  international 
accounting standards (IAS) to be adopted by companies or institutions and their auditing firms in 
preparing  financial  statements.  This  creates  a  sense  of  opacity  and  lack  of  homogeneity  in 

 

  

 

9

statutory financial reporting. For financial supervision reporting, there is no chart of accounts to 
be used that meets IAS. The Government has not yet developed generally accepted accounting 
principles (GAAP) or generally accepted auditing standards (GAAS). In most cases, accounting 
and  auditing  professionals  are  brought  in  from  India,  and  financial  reporting  standards  have 
followed  Indian  GAAP  and  GAAS  practices.  National  accounting  (and  auditing)  standards  and 
policies  are  necessary  to  ensure  comparability  of  reports,  reliability  of  information,  and 
transparency of financial information and so promote good corporate governance in Bhutan. 
 
29. 
Auditing  standards  and  guidelines  are  fragmented.  Internal  auditing  procedures  for 
financial  institutions  are  set  out  in  the  Companies  Act  (2000),  Prudential  Regulations  (2002), 
and FIA (1992). The auditing issue is exacerbated by financial institutions’ not always complying 
with statutory requirements to establish an independent audit committee and internal auditors. 
Financial institutions face difficulty hiring qualified internal auditors and chartered accountants, 
resulting in heavy dependence on foreign experts. Therefore, a unified national accounting body 
needs  to  be  established  to  draft  Bhutanese  accounting  and  auditing  policies  and  standards  to 
be adopted by companies and auditing firms serving Bhutan. To support the introduction of the 
new policies and standards, it is crucial that financial sector professionals and regulators have 
sufficient  training  and  knowledge  to  effectively  adopt  new  accounting  and  auditing  standards 
and rules. 
 

5. 

Insufficient Information Disclosure  

 
30. 
The  lack  of  a  reliable  borrower  information  system  impedes  bank  lending  and  brings 
weak risk assessment. In particular, this lack of timely and reliable information often contributes 
to the build up of NPLs and the subsequent adoption of very stringent collateral requirements, 
which curtail the ability of the private sector to access finance. Therefore, establishing a credit 
information bureau (CIB) or an arrangement for banks to share credit information is fundamental 
to  improving  credit  decisions  and  accelerating  credit  growth  in  this  regard.  In  Bhutan,  sharing 
credit  information  among  financial  institutions  is  difficult.  The  Government  has  been  keen  to 
develop a credit information-sharing system since 1997. However, with the very small scope of 
financial services then, an informal information-sharing arrangement without formal procedures 
or appropriate information technology (IT) infrastructure was recommended as sufficient for the 
banking  sector’s  level  of  development.20  Since  the  establishment  of  BNBL  in  1997  and  the 
removal  of  the  monopoly  position  of  BOBL,  along  with  the  active  participation  of  RICBL  and 
BDFCL, lending activities and products have increased. The need is apparent to develop a CIB 
with  an  appropriate  IT  system  for  (i)  enabling  financial  institutions  to  improve  their  credit 
judgments using the past credit experience of borrowers and knowledge regarding the incidence 
of defaults, (ii) speeding up loan applications, and (iii) facilitating the adjustment of premiums to 
credit risk. Convenient access to the credit profiles of customers would potentially lower the cost 
of  financial  intermediation  and  ensure  a  prudent  expansion  of  the  lending  business,  thereby 
improving enterprises’ access to finance. 
 
31. 
Insufficient information disclosure also imposes serious constraints to further developing 
the securities exchange. It is difficult to obtain up-to-date share prices for investment decisions. 
The lack of information available on listed companies in RSEBL has impeded the efficiency of 
transactions.  To  encourage  investors  to  enter  the  securities  market,  RSEBL  should  consider 
developing a website to strengthen investor access to trading and company information. A cost-
justified  exchange  website  can  improve  immensely  the  availability  and  timely  dissemination  of 
market information.

Secondly, the need is pressing for the draft FSA to be finalized and enacted to address 
gaps in the regulation and supervision of the whole financial sector of Bhutan. The small size of 
Bhutan’s economy makes it appropriate to have RMA as the single regulator. Therefore, under 
the  FSA,  RMA  is  to  be  vested  with  powers  to  license,  regulate,  and  supervise  all  financial

Risks and Safeguards 

B. 
 
103.  The FSDP design is based on lessons learned from earlier ADB assistance in Bhutan. 
The success and impact of the FSDP are subject to different types of risks of varying degrees. 
Mitigating measures have been incorporated in the FSDP as appropriate and possible.   
 
104.  While a potential risk to FSDP implementation is how the Government will implement the 
reforms  and  follow  through,  it  is  fully  committed  to  the  needed  reforms,  as  evidenced  by  its 
pronouncements  and  actions  taken  up  front.  The  work  on  strengthening  legal  provisions  for 
further  financial  sector  development—e.g.,  drafting  the  revised  RMA  Act  and  FSA—has  been 
progressing for some time, and official comments from other funding agencies (e.g., IMF) have 
been received and incorporated into the revised RMA Act and draft FSA. In addition, the draft 
acts will be finalized by the Government as conditions for loan effectiveness. The Government 
has  shown  strong  ownership  of  the  needed  financial  sector  reforms  through  extensive 
consultation with stakeholders and ADB. In addition, the revised RMA Act is to be enacted by 
end-2006  to  give  RMA  greater  autonomy  and  independence  to  carry  out  the  adequate 
regulation and supervision of all financial institutions and activities.   
 
105.  Another  potential  risk  to  program  implementation  is  the  inadequacy  of  institutional 
capacity  in  RMA  and  financial  institutions  to  carry  out  the  reform  agenda.  This  particularly 
entails the issues of (i) whether the new FSA will be fully understood and reviewed for passage; 
(ii) how strengthened rules and regulations are implemented, complied with, and enforced; and 
(iii)  whether  there  are  sufficient  resources  to  carry  out  program  implementation.  The  FSDP 
therefore  places  strong  emphasis  on  consultation  and  technical  training  for  new  rules  and 
regulations  to  ensure  awareness  and  broad  ownership  of  the  reforms.  More  specifically, 
training, including medium and long-term training and secondment programs will be provided to 
RMA  and  IAs  on,  among  other  topics,  regulatory  and  supervisory  skills,  securities  markets, 
insurance underwriting, and accounting and auditing. The piggy-backed TA will further enhance 
and  sustain  the  effectiveness  of  the  financial  training  for  the  regulatory  authority  and  financial 
professionals. 
 
106.  Resistance  from  vested  interests  to  certain  reform  measures  is  a  potential  risk.  This 
particularly  relates  to  strengthening  the  governance  structure  and  operations  of  financial 
institutions.  Potential  resistance  may  arise  from  the  reform  measures  affecting  corporate 
governance regulations regarding BOBL and RICBL. However, the Government has expressed 
strong commitment and further confirmed that the revised RMA Act will give the regulator, RMA, 
greater autonomy to regulate the whole financial sector, including corporate governance issues. 
The FSDP also has measures to ensure that RMA is able to regulate and take remedial action 
to  enforce corporate  governance  under  FSA  legislation  and  relevant  regulations. Furthermore, 
at the level of the individual financial institution, RICBL has taken the initiative to prepare a new 
business  plan  for  the  Credit  and  Investment  Department,  with  TA  support  from  SEDF,  and 
prepare  for  the  rationalization  of  its  own  operations.  Similarly,  BOBL  also  received  assistance

Capital  Adequacy.  The  minimum  capital  requirement  has  been  set  at  8%  of  risk-

Accounting Policies and Procedures, and Financial Reporting. Cash accounting 
is used by RMA. For MOF, the main accounting records are cash book, journal, and ledger. 
Accountability  rests  on  compliance  with  financial  regulations,  including  disbursement  rules,

disbursement officer, and accountant. A system of detailed pre-approvals reduces the scope

be kept. The PMU will implement RMA’s accounting processes and procedures, namely the

described above.

since  2003  for  standardizing  the  Government’s  budget  and  accounting  system,  but  the 
system  cannot  automatically  generate  necessary  project  financial  reports,  which  must  be

Audit  Arrangements.  The  internal  audit  department  at  RMA  reports  directly  to  the 
managing director of RMA, while the internal audit department at MOF reports directly to the 
finance minister and finance secretary. The Financial Rules and Regulations (2001) manual 
provides  only  simple  advice  on  managers’  responsibility  for  internal  controls  and  identifies 
some  of  the  main  areas  where  they  are  needed.  As  a  result,  incomplete  internal  controls 
arise  due  to  (i)  the  inability  by  managers  to  fully  understand  the  need  for  internal  controls 
and  (ii)  the  failure  of  managers  to  give  them  practical  effect.  Furthermore,  the  internal 
auditors  in  RMA  and  MOF  do  not  hold  recognized  professional  qualifications  such  as 
chartered  public  accountant.  Their  qualifications  are  based  on  experience  and  ad  hoc 
courses (auditing seminars, etc.).   
 
12. 
However, external audits conducted by the Royal Audit Authority deter irregularities 
and  ensure  basic  financial  accountability.  The  external  audits  of  MOF  and  RMA  are 
conducted  according  to  auditing  standards  of  the  International  Organization  of  Supreme 
Audit Institution. Project accounts will be audited by RMA’s internal auditor and externally by 
the Royal Audit Authority. The audited project financial statements will be submitted to ADB 
within 6 months of the end of the Government’s fiscal year on 30 June.    
 
13. 
Disbursement Arrangements. The ADB loan of $13 million will be disbursed over a 
period of 3 years. Disbursement from the ADB loan will be made in accordance with ADB’s 
Loan  Disbursement  Handbook.  The  imprest  account  procedure  will  be used for  the  project 
loan.  As  eligible  expenditures  are  incurred  and  paid  from  the  account,  the  EA  will  request 
liquidation  or  replenishment  of  the  account  by  submitting  a  withdrawal  application  on  a 
regular basis. Any balance of the advance not liquidated will be promptly refunded to ADB in 
the currency of the account. 

14. 
Supervision Plan. Capacity building and closer supervision will be required initially 
to ensure PMU compliance with the proposed systems as outlined. Normal supervision may 
be applied later.  
 
15. 
Conclusion  and  Recommendations.  More  detailed  guidance  and  more  intensive 
training  for  both  auditors  and  managers  are  required  to  make  the  internal  audit  units  fully 
effective. Many managers currently view their responsibilities primarily as the routine duties 
of authorizing payments, signing requests, and so on. Incomplete understanding of internal 
controls may generally influence attitudes toward internal audits, with detrimental effects on 
financial  management.  Furthermore,  the  internal  auditors  in  RMA  and  MOF  do  not  hold 
recognized professional qualifications such as chartered public accountant.

working  in  administration  and  finance,  and  other  managers  who  supervise  finances

practical  effect  to  these  internal  controls  and  (ii)  specialized  training  to  enhance  the 
qualifications  and  competency  of 
the 
Government’s financial management by improving qualification in accounting and auditing as

2. 
General  Context.  Recent  governance  reforms  in  Bhutan  have  focused  on 
devolution,  decentralization,  and  judicial  reforms.  The  role  of  the  legislature  has  been 
enhanced with the establishment of its public finance and public accounts committees and of 
the legislative committee. Administrative and financial decentralization has meant that more 
authority and accountability have passed to the districts and village blocks. The Royal Audit 
Authority  (RAA)  has  been  given  broad  powers  to  ensure  that  public  sector  entities  are 
audited regularly and that their accountability for usage of public funds is assured. While no 
specifically  identifiable  road  map  for  governance  has  yet  been  put  in  place  in  Bhutan,  the 
broad  outlines  of  a  core  governance-reform  program  are  captured  in  the  Government’s 
Bhutan  2020  vision  document  and  the  National  Poverty  Reduction  Strategy.  The  vision 
document  focuses  on  governance  in  regard  to,  among  other  areas,  the  management  of 
development,  professionalism  in  the  civil  service,  resource  mobilization,  and  development 
financing.  
 
3. 
Sector  Specific  Context.  The  finance  sector  in  Bhutan  is  still  at  a  relatively  early 
stage  of  development,  with  only  four  financial  institutions—two  banks  and  two  non-bank 
institutions, with the banks holding more than four-fifths of total assets in the financial sector. 
Still,  given  Bhutan’s  impressive  economic  growth  rates  over  time,  the  contribution  of  the 
financial  sector  has  substantially  expanded.  The  two  commercial  banks  (Bhutan  National 
Bank Limited and Bank of Bhutan Limited) operate at the low-risk end of the market (e.g., by 
requiring considerable collateral). Their growth (e.g., in assets) is slower than that of the two 
non-bank  financial  institutions,  with  fewer  nonperforming  loans.  There  is  some  competition 
among  financial  institutions,  but  innovative  financial  products  are  yet  to  be  developed  to 
entice the private sector.

4. 
Legislative  and  Policy  Framework.  The  legislative  basis  of  work  in  the  finance 
sector  is  primarily  contained  in  the  Royal  Monetary  Authority  Act  (1982),  Companies  Act 
(2000),  Bankruptcy  Act  (1999),  the  Financial  Institutions  Act  (1992),  and  the  proposed 
Financial Services Act (FSA). The FSA has provisions to increase RMA’s autonomy in the 
conduct  of  its  statutory  functions,  both  monetary  and  regulatory;  this  is  said  to  be  in 
alignment  with  Government’s  preference  to  go  slow  towards  a  full  central  bank.  Some 
internal  structural  changes  at  RMA  have  been  made  recently.  Despite  the  flurry  of  activity 
around drafting the FSA, legal gaps are still thought to exists in the finance sector in Bhutan. 
For  example,  no  existing  laws  or  regulations  supervise  the  insurance  industry  effectively. 
This  proposed  sector-development  loan  has  one  component  geared  specifically  for  this 
weakness. 
 
5. 
Capability  Issues.  Across  institutions  in  the  finance  sector  is  a  significant  lack  of 
institutional  capacity  building  and  skills  development.  RMA  is  particularly  concerned  about

these capacity constraints in financial institutions and wishes to put considerable emphasis 
on building institutional capability in this sector. Capability gaps are evident in such areas as 
on-site  inspection,  enforcement  procedures,  management  capability  in  commercial  banks, 
corporate  governance,  actuarial  evaluation,  internal  auditing,  and  the  loan  review  and 
monitoring systems. 
 
6. 
Regulatory  Framework.  This  revolves  around  the  role  of  RMA  and  its  use  of  the 
Financial  Institutions  Act  (1992)  as  a  tool  to  regulate  the  sector.  The  Royal  Insurance 
Corporation  of  Bhutan  Limited  (RICBL)  exercises  a  monopoly  in  insurance  services,  an 
industry that RMA is not felt to have full capacity to regulate because (i) the FIA (1992) does 
not  adequately  cover  the  subject  of  insurance  and  (ii)  well-trained  and  well-equipped 
regulatory  personnel  to  regulate  RICBL  are  lacking  in  RMA.  The  Financial  Institutions 
Supervision Division (FISD) of RMA plays a central role in enforcing prudential regulations in 
the finance sector, but there appears to be no clear rule by which RMA can impose penalties 
for  non-compliance.  While  penalties  for  any  infraction  of  the  prudential  regulations  are

the FIA and to their shareholders by the Companies Act. Financial institutions are required

The  discussion  of corruption  in the Bhutanese public sector is conditioned  by  there 
having  been  no  system-wide  corruption  assessments  or  analyses  conducted  to  date.  No 
comprehensive external assessments have been done either. What does exist is anecdotal 
evidence  regarding  what  is  generally  perceived  in  the  country.  Funding  agency  reports  on 
sectoral  assessments  point  out  that  the  Bhutanese  public  sector  is  remarkably  free  of 
institutional  corruption.  It  is  fair  to say  that  there  is  less  risk  in  Bhutan  of  system-wide  and 
institutionalized  corruption  in  the  public  sector  than  of  inefficiencies,  ineffectiveness, 
negligence, and malfeasance on the part of public servants. RAA audits show that financial 
institutions  suffer  from  the  same  types  of  managerial  lapses,  by  and  large,  that  are  in 
evidence  in  other  Government  departments,  including  lapses  in  over-payment,  lack  of 
adherence to specific requirements, etc.

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reducing poverty in Bhutan: 
Private sector  development is vital to fostering economic  growth and creating employment opportunities and so 
achieve the development goals of the Ninth Five-Year Development Plan (2002–2007). However, as the private 
sector continues to face several constraints because of its small domestic markets, lack of labor, underdeveloped 
infrastructure, and lack of adequate access to finance, the contribution of the private sector to the gross domestic 
product  has  yet  to  become  an  engine  of  economic  growth  or  poverty  reduction  in  Bhutan.  The  Government  of 
Bhutan  recognized  the  need  to  develop  the  financial  sector  to  support  private  sector  growth.  Lack  of  access  to 
finance,  high  interest  rates,  and  high  collateral  requirements  are  recognized  as  significant  drawbacks  for 
entrepreneurs and will be addressed with the objective of recommending means to improve the financial system. 
More  broadly,  competition  among  financial  institutions  seems  to  be  lacking,  which  hinders  the  development  of 
more  and  better  financial  products  and  services  such  as  leasing,  venture  capital,  credit  cards,  and  automated 
teller machines. Hence, the technical assistance will review and prepare a strategy to promote competition in the 
financial sector. 
 
The Project will support strengthening the financial system by promoting good governance in banking supervision 
and  insurance  regulation,  building  institutional  capacity,  and  encouraging  financial  competition  by  developing  a 
more efficient non-bank financial sector. Better financial intermediation provided by an improved financial system, 
including the non-bank financial sector, will likely increase the ratio of credit to the private sector as a percentage 
of total financial assets to more than the current 19% and the private sector contribution in manufacturing, trade 
and commerce, and services, as percentage of gross domestic product, from the current 34%. 
 
 
B. Poverty Analysis  
 
What type of poverty analysis is needed? 
Financial  intermediation  and  market  competition  improve  the  efficiency  of  resource  allocation  and  therefore 
enhance  private  sector  competition  and  entrepreneurship.  Greater  financial  development  generates  more 
employment,  induces  better  innovation,  and  augments  high  economic  productivity  to  provide  benefits  economy 
wide. 
 
The  social  benefits  will  be  explored  in  aggregate.  In  addition,  financial  development  underpins  private  sector 
development,  which  is  vital  to  the  economic  growth  of  Bhutan  as  expected  in  the  Ninth  Five-Year  Plan.  Higher 
private  sector  development  is  envisaged  to  absorb  the  70,000  new  labor  market  entrants,  stimulate  growth  in 
small and medium-sized enterprises, and improve national economic growth. The social and poverty impact will  
be  positive,  resulting  from  support  for  reforms  to  specific  financial  services,  products,  and  supervision  and 
regulation for targeted financial sectors, institutions, and/or beneficiaries.
